trans-unit.source: Get started with the DocumentDB .NET SDK | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with the DocumentDB .NET SDK | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create and configure an Azure DocumentDB account, create databases, create collections, and store JSON documents within your NoSQL document database account.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create and configure an Azure DocumentDB account, create databases, create collections, and store JSON documents within your NoSQL document database account.

trans-unit.source: Get started with the DocumentDB .NET SDK
trans-unit.target: Get started with the DocumentDB .NET SDK

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to get started using [Microsoft Azure DocumentDB](https://azure.microsoft.com/services/documentdb/) and the [DocumentDB .NET SDK](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB/).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to get started using [Microsoft Azure DocumentDB](https://azure.microsoft.com/services/documentdb/) and the [DocumentDB .NET SDK](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB/).

trans-unit.source: You'll build a console application that creates and queries DocumentDB resources, and writes the output to the console window.
trans-unit.target: You'll build a console application that creates and queries DocumentDB resources, and writes the output to the console window.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB is a NoSQL document database service, which has a [number of APIs and SDKs available](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn781482.aspx).
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB is a NoSQL document database service, which has a [number of APIs and SDKs available](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn781482.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The code in this article is written in C# and uses the DocumentDB .NET SDK, which is packaged and distributed as a NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: The code in this article is written in C# and uses the DocumentDB .NET SDK, which is packaged and distributed as a NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: The following scenarios are covered in this article:
trans-unit.target: The following scenarios are covered in this article:

trans-unit.source: Creating and connecting to a DocumentDB account
trans-unit.target: Creating and connecting to a DocumentDB account

trans-unit.source: Adding DocumentDB to your Visual Studio solution
trans-unit.target: Adding DocumentDB to your Visual Studio solution

trans-unit.source: Creating databases
trans-unit.target: Creating databases

trans-unit.source: Creating collections
trans-unit.target: Creating collections

trans-unit.source: Creating JSON documents
trans-unit.target: Creating JSON documents

trans-unit.source: Querying resources
trans-unit.target: Querying resources

trans-unit.source: Deleting databases
trans-unit.target: Deleting databases

trans-unit.source: Don't have time to complete the tutorial and just want to get the working solution?
trans-unit.target: Don't have time to complete the tutorial and just want to get the working solution?

trans-unit.source: No worries.
trans-unit.target: No worries.

trans-unit.source: The complete solution is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/tutorials/get-started).
trans-unit.target: The complete solution is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/tutorials/get-started).

trans-unit.source: See [Get the complete solution](#GetSolution) for quick instructions.
trans-unit.target: See [Get the complete solution](#GetSolution) for quick instructions.

trans-unit.source: Once you've completed the tutorial, please using the voting buttons at the beginning or end of the topic to let us know how we did.
trans-unit.target: Once you've completed the tutorial, please using the voting buttons at the beginning or end of the topic to let us know how we did.

trans-unit.source: This topic is actively being updated, so we want your feedback on improving it.
trans-unit.target: This topic is actively being updated, so we want your feedback on improving it.

trans-unit.source: If you'd like us to contact you, feel free to include your email address in the comment for follow-up.
trans-unit.target: If you'd like us to contact you, feel free to include your email address in the comment for follow-up.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before following the instructions in this article, you should ensure that you have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before following the instructions in this article, you should ensure that you have the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio 2013](http://www.visualstudio.com/) Update 4 or higher.
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio 2013](http://www.visualstudio.com/) Update 4 or higher.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a DocumentDB account
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a DocumentDB account

trans-unit.source: Lets get started by creating a DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: Lets get started by creating a DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: If you already have an account, you can skip to [Setup your Visual Studio Solution](#SetupVS).
trans-unit.target: If you already have an account, you can skip to [Setup your Visual Studio Solution](#SetupVS).

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Setup your Visual Studio Solution
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Setup your Visual Studio Solution

trans-unit.source: Open **Visual Studio** on your computer.
trans-unit.target: Open **Visual Studio** on your computer.

trans-unit.source: Select **New** from the **File** menu, and choose **Project**.
trans-unit.target: Select **New** from the **File** menu, and choose **Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the **New Project Dialog**, select **Templates** / **Visual C#** / **Console Application**, name your project, and then click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New Project Dialog**, select **Templates** / **Visual C#** / **Console Application**, name your project, and then click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Solution Explorer**, right click on your new console application, which is under your Visual Studio solution.
trans-unit.target: In the **Solution Explorer**, right click on your new console application, which is under your Visual Studio solution.

trans-unit.source: Then without leaving the menu, click on **Manage NuGet Packages...**
trans-unit.target: Then without leaving the menu, click on **Manage NuGet Packages...**

trans-unit.source: On the left most panel of the **Manage NuGet Packages** window, click **Online** / **nuget.org**.
trans-unit.target: On the left most panel of the **Manage NuGet Packages** window, click **Online** / **nuget.org**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Search Online** input box, search for **DocumentDB Client Library**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Search Online** input box, search for **DocumentDB Client Library**.

trans-unit.source: Within the results, find **Microsoft Azure DocumentDB Client Library** and click **Install**.
trans-unit.target: Within the results, find **Microsoft Azure DocumentDB Client Library** and click **Install**.

trans-unit.source: The package ID for the DocumentDB Client Library is [Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB)
trans-unit.target: The package ID for the DocumentDB Client Library is [Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB)

trans-unit.source: Great!
trans-unit.target: Great!

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to start working with DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to start working with DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Connect to a DocumentDB account
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Connect to a DocumentDB account

trans-unit.source: We'll start by creating a new instance of the [DocumentClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.aspx) class in order to establish a connection to our DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: We'll start by creating a new instance of the [DocumentClient](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.aspx) class in order to establish a connection to our DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: We'll need the following references at the beginning of our C# application:
trans-unit.target: We'll need the following references at the beginning of our C# application:

trans-unit.source: Next, a **DocumentClient** can be instantiated using the DocumentDB account endpoint and either the primary or secondary access key associated with the account.
trans-unit.target: Next, a **DocumentClient** can be instantiated using the DocumentDB account endpoint and either the primary or secondary access key associated with the account.

trans-unit.source: Add these properties to your class.
trans-unit.target: Add these properties to your class.

trans-unit.source: Let's now create a new asynchronous task called **GetStartedDemo** in your class.
trans-unit.target: Let's now create a new asynchronous task called **GetStartedDemo** in your class.

trans-unit.source: Within this new task, create and set up your **DocumentClient**.
trans-unit.target: Within this new task, create and set up your **DocumentClient**.

trans-unit.source: Call your asynchronous task from your Main method similar to the code below.
trans-unit.target: Call your asynchronous task from your Main method similar to the code below.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] Never store credentials in source code.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] Never store credentials in source code.

trans-unit.source: To keep this sample simple, the credentials are shown in the source code.
trans-unit.target: To keep this sample simple, the credentials are shown in the source code.

trans-unit.source: See [Azure Web Sites: How Application Strings and Connection Strings Work](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2013/07/17/windows-azure-web-sites-how-application-strings-and-connection-strings-work/) for information on how to store credentials in a production environment.
trans-unit.target: See [Azure Web Sites: How Application Strings and Connection Strings Work](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2013/07/17/windows-azure-web-sites-how-application-strings-and-connection-strings-work/) for information on how to store credentials in a production environment.

trans-unit.source: Take a look at our sample application on [GitHub](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/blob/master/tutorials/get-started/src/Program.cs) for an example on storing credentials outside of the source code.
trans-unit.target: Take a look at our sample application on [GitHub](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/blob/master/tutorials/get-started/src/Program.cs) for an example on storing credentials outside of the source code.

trans-unit.source: The values for EndpointUrl and AuthorizationKey are the URI and PRIMARY KEY for your DocumentDB account, which can be obtained from the [Keys](https://portal.azure.com) blade for your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: The values for EndpointUrl and AuthorizationKey are the URI and PRIMARY KEY for your DocumentDB account, which can be obtained from the [Keys](https://portal.azure.com) blade for your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: Screen shot of the Azure Preview portal, showing a DocumentDB account, with the ACTIVE hub highlighted, the KEYS button highlighted on the DocumentDB account blade, and the URI, PRIMARY KEY and SECONDARY KEY values highlighted on the Keys blade
trans-unit.target: Screen shot of the Azure Preview portal, showing a DocumentDB account, with the ACTIVE hub highlighted, the KEYS button highlighted on the DocumentDB account blade, and the URI, PRIMARY KEY and SECONDARY KEY values highlighted on the Keys blade

trans-unit.source: These keys grant administrative access to your DocumentDB account and the resources in it.
trans-unit.target: These keys grant administrative access to your DocumentDB account and the resources in it.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB also supports the use of resource keys that allow clients to read, write, and delete resources in the DocumentDB account according to the permissions you've granted, without the need for an account key.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB also supports the use of resource keys that allow clients to read, write, and delete resources in the DocumentDB account according to the permissions you've granted, without the need for an account key.

trans-unit.source: For more information about resource keys, see [Permissions](documentdb-resources.md#permissions) and [View, copy, and regenerate access keys](documentdb-manage-account.md#keys).
trans-unit.target: For more information about resource keys, see [Permissions](documentdb-resources.md#permissions) and [View, copy, and regenerate access keys](documentdb-manage-account.md#keys).

trans-unit.source: Now that you know how to connect to a DocumentDB account and create an instance of the **DocumentClient** class, let's take a look at working with DocumentDB resources.
trans-unit.target: Now that you know how to connect to a DocumentDB account and create an instance of the **DocumentClient** class, let's take a look at working with DocumentDB resources.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create a database
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create a database

trans-unit.source: A [database](documentdb-resources.md#databases) can be created by using the [CreateDatabaseAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.createdatabaseasync.aspx) method of the **DocumentClient** class.
trans-unit.target: A [database](documentdb-resources.md#databases) can be created by using the [CreateDatabaseAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.createdatabaseasync.aspx) method of the **DocumentClient** class.

trans-unit.source: A database is the logical container of document storage partitioned across collections.
trans-unit.target: A database is the logical container of document storage partitioned across collections.

trans-unit.source: Create your new database in your **GetStartedDemo** method after your **DocumentClient** creation.
trans-unit.target: Create your new database in your **GetStartedDemo** method after your **DocumentClient** creation.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Create a collection
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Create a collection

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] **CreateDocumentCollectionAsync** will create a new S1 collection, which has pricing implications.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] **CreateDocumentCollectionAsync** will create a new S1 collection, which has pricing implications.

trans-unit.source: For more details, please visit our [pricing page](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/documentdb/).
trans-unit.target: For more details, please visit our [pricing page](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/documentdb/).

trans-unit.source: A [collection](documentdb-resources.md#collections) can be created by using the [CreateDocumentCollectionAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.createdocumentcollectionasync.aspx) method of the **DocumentClient** class.
trans-unit.target: A [collection](documentdb-resources.md#collections) can be created by using the [CreateDocumentCollectionAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.createdocumentcollectionasync.aspx) method of the **DocumentClient** class.

trans-unit.source: A collection is a container of JSON documents and associated JavaScript application logic.
trans-unit.target: A collection is a container of JSON documents and associated JavaScript application logic.

trans-unit.source: The newly created collection will be mapped to a [S1 performance level](documentdb-performance-levels.md).
trans-unit.target: The newly created collection will be mapped to a [S1 performance level](documentdb-performance-levels.md).

trans-unit.source: The database created in the previous step has a number of properties, one of which is the [CollectionsLink](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.database.collectionslink.aspx) property.
trans-unit.target: The database created in the previous step has a number of properties, one of which is the [CollectionsLink](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.database.collectionslink.aspx) property.

trans-unit.source: With that information, we can now create a collection after our database creation.
trans-unit.target: With that information, we can now create a collection after our database creation.

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Create documents
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Create documents

trans-unit.source: A [document](documentdb-resources.md#documents) can be created by using the [CreateDocumentAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.createdocumentasync.aspx) method of the **DocumentClient** class.
trans-unit.target: A [document](documentdb-resources.md#documents) can be created by using the [CreateDocumentAsync](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.client.documentclient.createdocumentasync.aspx) method of the **DocumentClient** class.

trans-unit.source: Documents are user defined (arbitrary) JSON content.
trans-unit.target: Documents are user defined (arbitrary) JSON content.

trans-unit.source: The collection created in the previous step has a number of properties, one of which is the [DocumentsLink](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.documentcollection.documentslink.aspx) property.
trans-unit.target: The collection created in the previous step has a number of properties, one of which is the [DocumentsLink](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.documents.documentcollection.documentslink.aspx) property.

trans-unit.source: With that information, we can now insert one or more documents.
trans-unit.target: With that information, we can now insert one or more documents.

trans-unit.source: If you already have data you'd like to store in your database, you can use DocumentDB's [Data Migration tool](documentdb-import-data.md).
trans-unit.target: If you already have data you'd like to store in your database, you can use DocumentDB's [Data Migration tool](documentdb-import-data.md).

trans-unit.source: First, we need to create a **Parent**, **Child**, **Pet**, **Address** and **Family** class.
trans-unit.target: First, we need to create a **Parent**, **Child**, **Pet**, **Address** and **Family** class.

trans-unit.source: Create these classes by adding the following internal sub-classes.
trans-unit.target: Create these classes by adding the following internal sub-classes.

trans-unit.source: Next, create your documents within your **GetStartedDemo** async method.
trans-unit.target: Next, create your documents within your **GetStartedDemo** async method.

trans-unit.source: You have now created the following database, collection, and documents in your DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: You have now created the following database, collection, and documents in your DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: Diagram illustrating the hierarchical relationship between the account, the database, the collection, and the documents
trans-unit.target: Diagram illustrating the hierarchical relationship between the account, the database, the collection, and the documents

trans-unit.source: Step 7: Query DocumentDB resources
trans-unit.target: Step 7: Query DocumentDB resources

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB supports rich [queries](documentdb-sql-query.md) against JSON documents stored in each collection.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB supports rich [queries](documentdb-sql-query.md) against JSON documents stored in each collection.

trans-unit.source: The following sample code shows various queries - using both DocumentDB SQL syntax as well as LINQ - that we can run against the documents we inserted in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: The following sample code shows various queries - using both DocumentDB SQL syntax as well as LINQ - that we can run against the documents we inserted in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Add these queries to your **GetStartedDemo** async method.
trans-unit.target: Add these queries to your **GetStartedDemo** async method.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram illustrates how the DocumentDB SQL query syntax is called against the collection you created, and the same logic applies to the LINQ query as well.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram illustrates how the DocumentDB SQL query syntax is called against the collection you created, and the same logic applies to the LINQ query as well.

trans-unit.source: Diagram illustrating the scope and meaning of the query
trans-unit.target: Diagram illustrating the scope and meaning of the query

trans-unit.source: The [FROM](documentdb-sql-query.md/#from-clause) keyword is optional in the query because DocumentDB queries are already scoped to a single collection.
trans-unit.target: The [FROM](documentdb-sql-query.md/#from-clause) keyword is optional in the query because DocumentDB queries are already scoped to a single collection.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, "FROM Families f" can be swapped with "FROM root r", or any other variable name you choose.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, "FROM Families f" can be swapped with "FROM root r", or any other variable name you choose.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB will infer that Families, root,or the variable name you chose, reference the current collection by default.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB will infer that Families, root,or the variable name you chose, reference the current collection by default.

trans-unit.source: Step 8: Delete the database
trans-unit.target: Step 8: Delete the database

trans-unit.source: Deleting the created database will remove the database and all children resources (collections, documents, etc.).
trans-unit.target: Deleting the created database will remove the database and all children resources (collections, documents, etc.).

trans-unit.source: You can delete the database and the document client by adding the following code snippet to the end of your **GetStartedDemo** async method.
trans-unit.target: You can delete the database and the document client by adding the following code snippet to the end of your **GetStartedDemo** async method.

trans-unit.source: Step 9: Run your application!
trans-unit.target: Step 9: Run your application!

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to run your application.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to run your application.

trans-unit.source: At the end of your **Main** method, add the following line of code, which will let you read the console output before the application finishes running.
trans-unit.target: At the end of your **Main** method, add the following line of code, which will let you read the console output before the application finishes running.

trans-unit.source: Now hit F5 in Visual Studio to build the application in debug mode.
trans-unit.target: Now hit F5 in Visual Studio to build the application in debug mode.

trans-unit.source: You should now see the output of your get started app.
trans-unit.target: You should now see the output of your get started app.

trans-unit.source: The output will show the results of the queries we added and should match the example text below.
trans-unit.target: The output will show the results of the queries we added and should match the example text below.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you run the application multiple times without removing the database, you might run into the issue of creating a new database with an id already in use.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you run the application multiple times without removing the database, you might run into the issue of creating a new database with an id already in use.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this, you can check to see if a database, collection, or document with the same id already exists.
trans-unit.target: To avoid this, you can check to see if a database, collection, or document with the same id already exists.

trans-unit.source: For a reference on how this can be achieved, visit our [GitHub page](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/tutorials/get-started).
trans-unit.target: For a reference on how this can be achieved, visit our [GitHub page](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/tutorials/get-started).

trans-unit.source: Contratulations!
trans-unit.target: Contratulations!

trans-unit.source: You've created your first DocumentDB app!
trans-unit.target: You've created your first DocumentDB app!

trans-unit.source: Get the complete solution
trans-unit.target: Get the complete solution

trans-unit.source: To build the GetStarted solution that contains all the samples in this article, you will need the following:
trans-unit.target: To build the GetStarted solution that contains all the samples in this article, you will need the following:

trans-unit.source: [DocumentDB account][documentdb-create-account].
trans-unit.target: [DocumentDB account][documentdb-create-account].

trans-unit.source: The [GetStarted](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/tutorials/get-started) solution available on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: The [GetStarted](https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-net/tree/master/tutorials/get-started) solution available on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: To restore the references to the DocumentDB .NET SDK in Visual Studio 2013, right-click the **GetStarted** solution in Solution Explorer, and then click **Enable NuGet Package Restore**.
trans-unit.target: To restore the references to the DocumentDB .NET SDK in Visual Studio 2013, right-click the **GetStarted** solution in Solution Explorer, and then click **Enable NuGet Package Restore**.

trans-unit.source: Next, in the App.config file, update the EndpointUrl and AuthorizationKey values as described in [Connect to a DocumentDB account](#Connect).
trans-unit.target: Next, in the App.config file, update the EndpointUrl and AuthorizationKey values as described in [Connect to a DocumentDB account](#Connect).

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Want a more complex ASP.NET MVC sample?
trans-unit.target: Want a more complex ASP.NET MVC sample?

trans-unit.source: See [Build a web application with ASP.NET MVC using DocumentDB](documentdb-dotnet-application.md).
trans-unit.target: See [Build a web application with ASP.NET MVC using DocumentDB](documentdb-dotnet-application.md).

trans-unit.source: Learn how to [monitor a DocumentDB account](documentdb-monitor-accounts.md).
trans-unit.target: Learn how to [monitor a DocumentDB account](documentdb-monitor-accounts.md).

trans-unit.source: Run queries against our sample dataset in the [Query Playground](https://www.documentdb.com/sql/demo).
trans-unit.target: Run queries against our sample dataset in the [Query Playground](https://www.documentdb.com/sql/demo).

trans-unit.source: Learn more about the programming model in the Development section of the [DocumentDB documentation page](../../services/documentdb/).
trans-unit.target: Learn more about the programming model in the Development section of the [DocumentDB documentation page](../../services/documentdb/).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
